POLICE JUNIOR OFFICERS
(New structure and salary scales)
(Statement by the Minister for Home Affairs)


    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: Mr Speaker, Sir, during the Parliamentary session in October, 1971, the Minister for Finance informed the House that the Lee Soo Ann Committee's recommendations on the structure and salary scales for the Junior Officers and Constables of the Regular Police Force had been accepted in principle by Government and would be implemented in the new fiscal year on 1st April, 1972. He stated that as soon as the principles of conversion were resolved, the new salary scales would be implemented. The House was also informed that pending implementation of the new salary scales on the 1st of April this year, Government had decided that the Junior Officers and Constables should be given with effect from the 1st of November, 1971, an interim allowance of 10 per cent of salary and of all allowances drawn, except Public Utilities Board and Housing Allowances.

Column: 1058



    I am pleased to announce that Government has accepted in principle most of the other recommendations of the Lee Soo Ann Committee Report. Officials of my Ministry and the Finance Ministry have been working closely together and a formula of conversion has now been worked out and approved by Government. The new total emoluments will be computed on the following basis: 

              Salary as at 1-4-72

                       +

           Allowances to be abolished

                       +

       Interim  allowance of 10  per  cent

       (made up of 10 per cent  of  salary 

       and of all allowances drawn, except 

       P.U.B, and Housing Allowances)

       Convert to the nearest higher point 

       in the new scale

                       +

           Increment credits(if any)

                       +

      Allowances to be retained (if any).
The conversion will come into effect on 1st April, 1972, and, as from that date, payment of the 10 per cent interim allowance will cease. The conversion to

Column: 1059

the new salary scales, including the allowances to be retained, will cost the Government an additional $3.2 million per annum.

    About 5,220 Junior Officers and Constables in the Regular Police Force, excluding members of the Gurkha Contingent and the Guard and Escort Unit, will be affected by the conversion. Those holding the rank of Corporal and below will be emplaced on the new salary scale for Constables. Staff Sergeants and Sergeants will be emplaced on the new scale for Sergeants. Sub-Inspectors will be absorbed as Assistant Inspectors, who will also be known as Station Inspectors. All serving officers will convert to the new salary scales as follows:

    (a) those with the School Certificate or equivalent qualifications will convert to the appropriate new scale in accordance with the conversion formula and progress up the scale in the normal way;

    (b) those with Secondary Il/Ill or equivalent qualifications will convert to the appropriate new scale in accordance with the conversion formula. They will not proceed beyond $425 in the new scale for Constable; $505 in the new scale for Sergeant and $690 in the new scale for Assistant Inspector (Station Inspector), as the case may be, until such time as they obtain the School Certificate or pass an examination to be conducted by the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Public Service Commission and accepted as an equivalent to the School Certificate, when they will be allowed to cross the bar at these points;

    (c) those without Secondary II but with specialist qualifications, e.g, bandsmen, helmsmen and engine drivers (about 170 of them) will convert in the same way as for category (b) above;

    (d) those without Secondary II or specialist qualifications (about 800 in number) will convert to the appropriate

Column: 1060

new scale in accordance with the conversion formula and be dealt with as follows.

    Government has accepted the recommendation that serving officers without Secondary II or equivalent qualifications should be converted to the new salary scales and stagnate at their respective points of conversion. Of the 800 men who do not have the Secondary II or specialist qualifications, 340 would be eligible for retirement in the normal course of events before 1st July, 1974. These 340 men will convert to the new salary scales and remain at their respective conversion points until they retire.

    The remaining 460 men will convert to the new salary scales and be retired on enhanced terms specifically provided in Section 9 (1) of the Pensions Act as recommended by the Lee Soo Ann Committee Report. Retirement under this provision gives an enhanced pension factor of One over five hundred (1/500) of an officer's annual pensionable emoluments for each complete month of pensionable service, as compared to a pension factor of one over six hundred (1/600) for an officer who retires in normal circumstances on account of age or for medical reasons. It is the intention of Government that the retirement of these 460 men will be so phased out that actual retirement will commence on 1st April, 1973, and be completed by 30th June, 1974. Those who are physically fit will be offered employment with the Guard and Escort Unit, which will by then have been reorganised into a statutory board and run on commercial lines, if they take up employment with this statutory board, they will be eligible, in addition to their pensions, for the full salary paid by the board. Efforts will also be made to assist those in Police quarters to find alternative accommodation.

2.37 p.m.

    Head 1401 -

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1101.

    Sir, may I request the Minister for Home Affairs to inform the House as to how many political parties there are on the Register of Societies today, and whether they are alive and functioning? If they are not, will the Minister consider introducing amending legislation to the Societies Act to remove all these dead-wood organisations from the Register, thereby protecting the people from the dupery of so-called political parties which resuscitate when general elections approach and promise the people nirvana-plus? Sir, if this mischievous practice of political parties of merely securing their registration is allowed to continue unchecked, our City State will in no time hold such an assortment of rackets that our people may turn politically frigid, and astute visitors to our country leave in bemused bewilderment at the spectacle we offer. Sir, in the name of rational freedom, I call upon the Minister to avoid turning our beautiful Republic into a museum of political parties.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. Wong Lin Ken): Mr Speaker, Sir, as on the 17th of March this year, there are 15 political parties registered on the Register of Societies. They are:

    (1) Singapore Chinese Party, formerly Malayan Chinese Association, Singapore Branch, registered on the 26th September, 1950;

    (2) Persatuan Melayu Singapura, formerly Persatuan Melayu Semenanjong, i.e., the Peninsula Malays Union, registered on the 2nd February, 1952;

Column: 1062



    (3) Partai Rakyat, Singapore State Division, registered on the 3rd December, 1956;

    (4) Angkatan Islam, formerly Pan Malayan Islamic Party, Singapore, registered on the 6th August, 1958;

    (5) Workers' Party, registered on the 30th January, 1961;

    (6) People's Action Party, registered on the 18th February, 1961;

    (7) Pertubohan Kebangsaan Melayu, Singapura, formerly Pertubohan Kebangsaan Melayu Bersatu, Singapura, i.e., the United Malays National Organisation, Singapore, registered on 20th of February, 1961;

    (8) United People's Party, registered on the 14th July, 1961;

    (9) Barisan Sosialis, registered on the 15th August, 1961;

    (10) Parti Kesatuan Ra'ayat, i.e., the United Democratic Party, registered on the 18th June, 1962;

    (11) Singapore Indian Congress, formerly the Malaysian Indian Congress, Singapore, registered on the 7th August,. 1962;

    (12) Alliance Party Singapura, registered on the 17th February, 1966;

    (13) United National Front, registered on the 6th March, 1970;

    (14) National Party of Singapore, registered on the 26th February, 1971;

    (15) People's Front, registered on the 21st May, 1971.

    Of these 15 parties, the following parties have not complied with the Societies Act requiring their constitution to be amended to provide for membership to be confined to Singapore citizens. These parties are:

    (1) Partai Rakyat, Singapore State Division;

    (2) Angkatan Islam;

    (3) Workers' Party; and

    (4) Barisan Sosialis.

    It is also relevant to note that of the 15 listed parties, Parti Kesatuan Ra'ayat, i.e., the United Democratic Party, has ceased to function, while the

Column: 1063

United People's Party and the Singapore Indian Congress are apparently inactive.

    Under section 6 of the Societies Act, the Registrar of Societies has powers to declare societies as deemed to cease to exist should they be unable to furnish him with proof of their existence. The Registrar of Societies has not taken action against dormant political parties and those which have not complied with the Societies Act. In view of the fact that the Registrar of Societies has sufficient powers to remove dead-wood political organisations, there is no need to amend the Societies Act to provide him with such power. In any case, there are politicians outside this Parliament who do not share the same down-to-earth views about dormant political parties as the Member for Changi. They believe in flogging a dead horse to life oblivious of past records of undistinguished performance.

2.45 p.m.

    As for Singapore becoming a museum of political parties, I am afraid this is part of history. As to the possibility of confusing the people of Singapore because of the large number of political parties, I submit, our electorate is an intelligent electorate.

    Hon. Members: Hear! hear!

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: Sir, the Minister has said that the Registrar of Societies has got the full power of deregistering any political parties if they are defunct or inactive. I do not know why no such action has been taken. Can the Minister explain to the House?

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: The reason is very simple. We do hope that there will be some other people who would like to revive dormant political parties and save them the bother of registration.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo: In view of the explanation, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1151*.(* The same amendment also stood in the, names of Messrs Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi, J. F. Conceicao and P. Govindaswamy.)

    In moving this amendment, Sir, I wish to speak on the Police Force. You will recall that during the debate on last year's Budget, I pointed out that some constables and Police officers were rude to members of the public. At that time the then Minister expressed concern over this issue and promised to take appropriate action to rectify the position. I am glad to note that since then members of the Police Force have shown a new style of behaviour in carrying out their services. The Police have been very active in some campaigns to bring about a better public understanding of the Police Force. For example, during Police Week they have put up road safety exhibitions in the community centres to bring about a better relationship and an improvement in co-operation between the people and the Police, and to make the people understand that the policeman is a friend of the people. These are some achievements which are praiseworthy. Undoubtedly a rapport between the Police and the people is meaningful in Singapore, because this, will promote the co-operation between the people and the Police, thereby enabling the Police Force to be more effective in crime prevention and detection. However, in the interests of the public, I wish to bring up two points.

    Firstly, the Police Week should be held annually in order to continue to improve the relationship between the people and the Police. It is only when there is co-operation between them that we can hope to achieve greater stability and better social order in our country so that our people will be able to live in peace.

    Secondly, in recruiting Police officers we must recruit more citizens. Sir, the Minister has said in a Statement earlier

Column: 1065

on that there has been a considerable improvement in the remuneration of Police officers. Therefore, I should think that this new salary structure is enough attraction to Singapore youths to join the Police Force. If this should fail to attract our own youths, then we have to make a further review and to study the causes. I would also like to ask the Minister concerned how many non-citizens have been recruited into the Police Force.

    Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan) (in Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has launched several campaigns, such as the Industrial Safety Campaign, Pedestrian Safety Campaign and Road Safety Campaign. To ensure the safety of members of the public on the roads and to prevent them from accidents which are, of course, avoidable, several road safety measures have been provided and a lot of money spent on them. For example, overhead bridges have been constructed and zebra crossing lines painted on the roads. All these are for the safety of pedestrians. But such campaigns and measures will be meaningless if all kinds of road users, either pedestrians, motorists or motor cyclists, still meet with accidents.

    One contribution to road accidents is that children are allowed to fly their kites anywhere they like. Sometimes these kite flyers can be seen by the roadsides, running across roads, and in many other places which are dangerous. This is a hazard to motorists and, apart from accidents that can happen to them, the kite flyers themselves can be knocked down by cars. The time has come for the Commissioner of Police to take firm measures against these kite flyers.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, how many policemen have resigned from the Force? Quite a number, I think; enough to create a staffing problem that can be described as critical. May I ask the Minister concerned why has this problem been allowed to deteriorate to such a state? Is it because of

Column: 1066

lack of esprit de corps in the Force? Or is it because of the bullying attitudes of the superior officers who, in the execution of their duty, may tend to be highhanded, or is it because of the poor pay structure? The Minister has announced a new pay structure for the Police Force, and it is most probable that Police officers will welcome it very much. Therefore, I hope they will work harder in future.

    Sometime ago we heard of a few Police officers who were sacked and then reinstated all because of a few missing Playboy magazines, which are banned in Singapore. Why was it that no action was taken against the person who was in possession of those bad magazines? Can it be said that the action against these four poor Police officers could have a demoralising effect in the Police Force, and thereby causing some to resign?

    It is encouraging to note that the Police Force is going to be modernised and reorganised but those responsible for the reorganisation should take the humane values into consideration. I hope that in the computerisation of the Police Force the policemen will not exist as mere digits in the minds of those responsible for the reorganisation. The chances of promotion in the Republic's Police Force should not only be given to people holding requisite qualifications, but equal chances should also be given to those with long service and with good records.

    May I also ask why at present the traffic is in a chaotic state? What is the number of traffic policemen at present in the Force, and how many of them are on traffic duty at any one time? Why is it a common sight in Singapore's roads to find traffic policemen on duty in pairs, in threes or in fours? It is time that more traffic policemen were on foot duty at junctions of busy roads, particularly in narrow lanes where most of the traffic offences are committed.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong) (in Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, please permit me to ask the Minister a question. This is in relation to the security

Column: 1067

of the Central Fish Market in Jurong. The Central Fish Market in Jurong is the only venue for the auction of fresh fish. Every day thousands of people do their fish business in this market. Because of the great number of people entering and leaving the market, it is inevitable that some bad hats mingle themselves with the crowd. As a result there have been cases of fighting, Xamb1ing and theft in the market.

    I have received complaints from the fish merchants in the market to the effect that over the past few months the security of the market has deteriorated. There has been an increasing number of thefts in the market. Fish packed in crates are simply stolen. For every crate of fish stolen the fishmonger loses about $100 to $200. If it is a crate of prawns, then the loss will be about $1,000. Those fish merchants who were affected have reported the cases to the Police, but were told that they could not do anything. I am told that usually the theft occurs before auction begins. This is the time when the businessmen are so busily occupied with the preparations for the auction that the thieves move in. I would like to ask the Minister whether he can send some policemen there between the hours of 10.00 p.m. and 2.00 a.m, to maintain order and security in the fish market.

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: Sir, first let me say how much I appreciate the statement from the Member for Sembawang that the Police Force has improved in its courtesy to the public. I am very pleased to hear that. The Member has also raised the question that we should, in fact, make the Police Week an annual affair. The Ministry has this in mind, and will certainly give the proposal every serious consideration. I am also very pleased to note that the series of 12 Police Week shows, which began last year and will continue in the present year, have produced the desired effect of establishing a better relationship between the Police and the public. The House can rest assured that the Police Force will be instructed that good Police relationship is not just a matter of Police

Column: 1068

shows. This should be a continuing daily experience between the Police and the public.

3.00p.m.

    The Member for Sembawang also raised the question of the recruitment of non-citizens. I think what he has in mind is the recruitment of Malaysians into the Police Force. The reason for this is simply that under the previous salary scales, before the present revision recommended by the Lee Soo Ann Report, it was found impossible to recruit Singapore citizens into the Police Force. I do share his hope that with the improvement in salary scales and also the conditions of work, we will have more Singaporeans applying to join the Police Force in our next recruitment exercise.

    I believe the Member has also asked for the figures of Malaysians recruited. I am unable to give him the exact figure, but if he wishes he can ask an Oral Question later. If he will be satisfied with a rough figure, it is in the region of 600. I would like to add that the recruitment of foreigners is only an interim measure, and we hope that in the future we do not have to recruit people from outside Singapore to fill up the Police Force.

    The Member for Kampong Kembangan raised the question of public safety, particularly with regard to kite-flying. Under section 14 (e) of the Minor Offences Act (Chapter 102), it is an offence for any person to fly a kite which obstructs or interferes with the traffic in any public road or with the use of telephones wires. The flying of kites is a seasonal past-time indulged in by young and old throughout the Republic. I believe it is a common feature in the Geylang Serai area. However, to-date there has been no occasion for the Police to take action against these persons because they have not obstructed or interfered with the traffic, and there has been no complaint of telephone wires having been damaged. The danger arising from this past-time is caused by children running after kites that have

Column: 1069

been cut loose. I can assure the Member that the Police will do all it can to prevent any hazard arising out of flying of kites, and I do hope that the Member will also urge people who wish to fly kites to be more careful.

    Sir, there are also a few questions raised by the Member for Anson. I believe he wanted to know how many policemen have resigned, and I can give him the figures. The number of resignations of junior officers was 122 for 1969, 246 for 1970, and 235 for 1971. From the beginning of this year to the 15th March, 1972, there were only 12 resignations. For senior officers, the number of resignations was 12 for 1969, 19 for 1970, and 24 for 1971. From the beginning of this year till the 20th March, 1972, there were only nine resignations. I think the House is fully aware of the reasons for the resignations, namely, the salary scales and the conditions of work. All this has been removed by the recommendations of the Lee Soo Ann Report, which the Government has accepted in principle. It is hoped that with the improvements in salary scales and conditions of work, there will be less resignations in future.

    I believe the Member for Anson is also concerned with the state of traffic in Singapore. If I heard him correctly, he described it as chaotic. Although traffic on our roads appears to be apparently chaotic, it is, in fact, not so. There are two vivid patterns in the flow of traffic - into the city in the morning peak, and out of the city in the evening peak. During these periods, the flow of traffic is congested, and I have no doubt that this congestion must have given rise to the impression that the flow of traffic is chaotic. With more vehicles on the roads during peak hours, the journeys to and from work create great demands on road space and certain delays are inevitably experienced. This is a common occurrence not only in Singapore, but in all big cities in the world. The Government is trying to overcome some of the problems of traffic congestion by making improvements to the network of roads and to traffic management

Column: 1070

and enforcement schemes. It is also relevant for me to point out that normally we do not deploy three or four traffic policemen on traffic duty in one spot, except in places where we have recently introduced the box junction system. I quite agree that we do need more traffic policemen, but I hope that as all the vacancies in the rank and file are filled, the position will be improved.

    The Member for Jurong raised the question of security in the Central Fish Market in Jurong. As this matter has just been pointed out to me, I will certainly look into it to see that the situation is improved.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has not replied to my question regarding the Playboy magazines.

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: If the Member is referring to the particular case of Playboy magazines, which I think he has in mind, that case has been investigated into and dealt with according to the instructions of the Attorney-General's Chambers. I believe the office concerned has already reinstated the officers.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Minister for his answers, and I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1251.

    Sir, every family has a law and every nation has a statute of laws. A nation enacts laws in order to maintain order in its society. However, if the enforcement of the law is ineffective, or worse, if the law is abused, there will be disharmony among members of the family and they will lose confidence in the enforcers of the law. If this goes on, the law will be flouted and in the end it will be very difficult to maintain law and order in the society. If I may use a colloquial phrase it is like an entanglement of the strands of jute.

Column: 1071



    Human beings are like social animals. They live together but because of civilisation they have advanced both socially and materially. Therefore, with the rising desire and expectation for progress they have differed in their mental make-up. This, together with the different levels of education that they receive, we find that there are the capable and the incapable, the stupid and the intelligent. Therefore, even in a very simple society, there is bound to be a certain number of people who are evil-doers. Among them there are those who have breached the law once or twice, while there are others who are incorrigible criminals. They break the law in order to achieve their ulterior motives. They try to create trouble and cause chaos. The Government, in order to safeguard the interests of the people, has to set up police stations, and send policemen and other officers in plain-clothes for patrol duties to prevent these evil-doers from breaking the law and to help the people to cope with emergencies.

    However, some members of the public in my constituency have complained to me that people have been wrongly arrested and beaten up by plain-clothes officers. I have carried out investigations into such complaints and have found them to be true. Hence, I would like to say something about this matter.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is said that whenever the Police arrest a suspect, he will first be beaten up to be taught a lesson. Sometimes he has to make a statement under duress. If this kind of approach is used against proven gangsters, I would be the last to object. On the contrary, I feel that more severe punishment should be meted out against such bad elements to stop them from doing bad things. However, the indiscriminate beating-up of suspects can sometimes involve innocent persons. I therefore feel that whenever the Police arrest certain suspects, they should first be interrogated and investigations made. The Police should check their identity to find out whether or not they have any previous criminal records. If they have no records, then investigations should be carried out at the scene of the crime.

Column: 1072

And if the suspects are found innocent, they should be released. If they are found guilty, they should be duly dealt with. Those who are guilty will not resist arrest, and will submit to punishment. In this way, the innocent will be spared corporal punishment. It is important to see that there is justice in the enforcement of the law. Then the country as a whole will be peaceful.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, plain-clothes Police officers are charged with the responsibility of safeguarding the peace of the country. They should not only be given privilege to be armed with revolvers but also the privilege to use them in self-defence. However, the use of firearms should only be resorted to when they are in very great danger. In a normal situation the Police should not use firearms.

3.15 p.m.

    There should be justice in the enforcement of law and order. This will promote a close rapport between the Police and the people. We should educate the people to be more friendly towards the Police Force. To accomplish this, I feel that all suspects should be thoroughly interrogated before any action is taken against them. If this is not done, there will be a miscarriage of justice and there will be hostility towards the Police. If suspects are taken to the Police station, and there are sufficient grounds to find them guilty, they should be charged accordingly. I hope the Minister will take note of what I have said so that a close rapport can be established between the Police and the public.

    Prof. Wong Lin Ken: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me first say that I share the views of the Member for Paya Lebar that law and order should be maintained and that justice should not only be done but is seen to be done. The main thrust of his debate is that some plain-clothes officers have beaten up suspects and that he himself has conducted an investigation into the matter. I appreciate the Member's good intention. However, I would like to say that if there are any complaints, there

Column: 1073

is a proper procedure to deal with them. He himself has conducted an investigation, but the results of his investigation cannot be the basis for disciplinary action. If he were to lodge a complaint, and if it is found that what he says is true, then disciplinary action will be taken against the officers concerned. Police officers are not above the law. There are specific provisions in the Penal Code which make it an offence for persons, including Police officers, to use force of any kind to extract confession or information which may lead to the detection of a crime.
